title: About
text:
Hi, my name is Luke Li and I am a rising senior at Lexington High School (Year of Graduation 2026).
Github: https://github.com/lukearoni
Email: lukelex2008@gmail.com
This project is about establishment entry rates of different metropolitan areas in the US. Here is the link to the github repository: https://github.com/lukearoni/business-success
This project was created as a part of Kane‚Äôs Data Science Bootcamp.

title: New Businesses in Different Areas
text: Establishment entry rates vary amongst different metropolitan areas. We obtained a dataset containing business dynamics data from the US Census Bureau, including the 2022 establishment entry and exit rates for each metropolitan area. This records the number of new shops, startups, or franchise buildings divided by the total number of establishments in that area during 2022. We seek to use this data to find the metropolitan areas with the highest rate. Sheridan, Wyoming is a high outlier for establishment entry rates, with an over 6% increase from the second highest, while the rest of the top 20 metropolitan area entry rates don‚Äôt differ by more than 2.2%.

title: New Businesses in Different Areas

Model 1 (for plot 1) \[
\text{net\_job\_creation\_rate}_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{estabs\_entry\_rate}_i + \epsilon_i
\]
Model 2 (for plot 2) \[
\text{job\_creation\_rate\_births}_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 \cdot \text{estabs\_entry\_rate}_i + \epsilon_i
\]
The first model examines the relationship between the net job creation rate and the establishment entry rate. It is specified as a simple linear regression where the net job creation rate for observation ùëñ is modeled as a function of a constant intercept term \(\beta_0\), the establishment entry rate multiplied by its slope coefficient \(\beta_1\), and a random error term \(\epsilon_i\), capturing unexplained variation. This model quantifies how changes in the rate at which new establishments enter the market are associated with overall net changes in employment within a state or region.
The second model similarly uses a linear regression framework to relate the job creation rate from births to the establishment entry rate. Here, the dependent variable is the job creation rate attributed specifically to new business births, modeled as a linear function of the establishment entry rate, an intercept, and a random error term. Both models assume linearity and normally distributed residuals, providing a basis to estimate and test the statistical significance of the association between business entry dynamics and employment growth.

title: Sources
text:
US Census Bureau 2022 Business Dynamics Statistics Dataset (MSA)
US Census Bureau Metropolitan Area Code and Area Name (Mar.¬†2020)
US Census Bureau Annual Metropolitan and Micropolitan Statistical Area Resident Population Estimates by Age, Sex, Race, and Hispanic Origin for the United States: April 1, 2020 to July 1, 2024 (CBSA-EST2024-ALLDATA-CHAR)
US Census Bureau Building Permits by CBSA 2019 - Present
Annual Residential Housing Units Authorized by Building Permits For Wyoming and Counties: 1987 to 2024
We obtained the data by using the US Census Bureau Datasets. From those datasets, we converted them to csv files and added them to the project. We did not have to wrangle the data much, only changing column names for ease of use as well as eliminating duplicate data. We also dropped data that had any not available information.
